'Smith Tower' is a skyscraper in Pioneer Square in Seattle, Washington.
Completed in 1914, the 38-story, tower is the oldest skyscraper in the city and
was the tallest office building west of the Mississippi River until the Kansas
City Power & Light Building was built in 1931. It remained the tallest building
on the West Coast until the Space Needle overtook it in 1962.

Smith Tower is named after its builder, firearm and typewriter magnate Lyman
Cornelius Smith, and is a designated Seattle landmark.
